text:
INCORPORATION.

Since our last issue this question has assumed a new phase. Instead of calling a public meeting at which the views of the people could have been heard, a few prominent citizens drafted and signed a large number of signatures to a petition to the North West Colonial government for incorporation and defining the eastern limits of the town as between the Hudson Bay Company's town site and Mr. John Macdonald's property. The residents of the east end requested to be included in the proposed town limits, but their privilege being denied them they have sent another petition requesting that, if the town be incorporated, their property shall be included. This will mean the incorporation of both petitions and the drafting of a General Municipal Ordinance, under which we will have to apply for incorporation.

OBITUARY.

The death is announced of Hon. Wm Elder, Provincial Secretary of New Brunswick. Mr. Elder, who was a member of the Protestant ministry, in which he labored for several years, was a brilliant scholar, having studied at Edinburgh, Dublin and Glasgow Universities. He mourned his death most profoundly; however, and may be said to have been the George Brown of New Brunswick. For many years he has been the editor and proprietor of the St. John Telegraph, the oldest Liberal newspaper in the Province, and was acknowledged to be one of the most finished writers and speakers in Canada. A few months ago he became the Provincial Secretary of the Blair administration, and the success of which he contributed much. His death will be a serious loss to the Liberal party and press of New Brunswick.

WHO MAKES OUR LAWS?

We endorse the statement of the Toronto Telegram when it says: "The English press is once more discussing the giddy young Marquis of Randolph. The last time it discussed him was in connection with a scandal in which the young man was involved, but not a contemptible part. This time it is in connection with his election to the dukedom of Marlborough. He is reported to be one of the most immoral respectable persons in English society, which, to say the least, can hardly be said to be flattering. The fact that by the most accidental birth he has been placed beyond the reach of bodily harm, enables him to rank the duke and also to a seat in the House of Lords, where he will make laws for the benefit of more respectable members. This is one of the beauties of the English system of primogeniture, by which the eldest son or next of kin steps into a vacant chair in the Lords, no matter though he be the biggest rascal in the three kingdoms. What chance would such a man have of being made a peer of those who sit in the House of Lords were chosen by the people whom they are supposed to represent?"

THE LONDON HORROR.

A little more than two years ago London was dismayed by the disastrous results of a calamity which at that time visited the city, and once more the hand of the destroyer has been laid upon her. The inhabitants of London were treated to a Friday evening of the 14th July, and the morning they were called upon to wage a desperate struggle with the elements, the horrors of which will remain fresh in the memories of those who participated in the battle against the forces of nature. The loss of life is put down at about twenty. Under the circumstances it is surprising that it was not greater. It is impossible as yet to estimate the loss to property. In the words of the London Evening News, "a population of upwards of 2,000 persons have been well nigh bereft and at least a score of lives have been lost. About a score of houses have been destroyed and perhaps three or four times that number wrecked by being floated away from their foundations and stranded on the streets or upon the banks of the river." It will be many days before the inhabitants of the flooded valley recover from the disastrous effects of the late calamity. Much hard work will have to be done before the victims of this disaster have been rendered completely destitute. So far the burden of assisting the victims has been left to the City of London, whose inhabitants have been very generous. Much will still require to be done, however, and some general scheme should be adopted. There is not a town or village in the Province Ontario but would contribute substantially to a general relief fund.

THE MERCER HEAT CASE.

The Mercer case has been before the courts for the last twelve years and has been the subject of a political storm as well as the center of a great party division. The action of the Ontario Government has, however, been sustained by the highest legal authority in the country. The point at issue out of the case of the late Andrew Mercer, a wealthy citizen of Toronto who died intestate in 1871. Every effort was made to lay claim to the property without any title. The real estate held by Mr. Mercer was eventually transferred to the Crown, who was claimed to be represented in Ontario by the late Mr. Justice Gordon. In the meantime, however, Mr. Andrew Mercer, an illegitimate son of the deceased, had taken possession of the property and disputed the title of the Crown. The case was finally decided by the Court of Chancery. The Vice-Chancellor overruled the demurrer. His decision was applauded, one of the pleas being that Mr. Mercer had been without heirs and the estate consequently having escheated to the Crown should revert to the Dominion which alone represented the Crown. This decision was rejected by the Ontario Court of Appeal. The decision of the Ontario Court was appealed and reversed by the Supreme Court. The Ontario government has determined to appeal to the case to the Privy Council which will give a decision in their favor. Apart altogether from party lines the decision will assist in settling the powers of the Provincial Governments.

CROP PROSPECTS.

From all parts of the District we are in receipt of the most encouraging reports of the crops. Hay is abundant, but very few of our farmers have as yet commenced to cut. Very favorable weather the cut deserves to be delayed. Of the grain and root crops it may be too early to speak, but as some of the grain is beginning to ripen, we are in hopes that any danger from frost is now over. We have seen some oats eight weeks old, which are full headed and almost ripe already to harvest. Altogether the initial signs are that we may average yield of from thirty to forty bushels per acre. The wheat is naturally abundant over the prospects and they certainly are to be congratulated. From other parts of Canada we have been encouraged reports. Apparently the season has been unusually dry and later reports tell of rather severe frosts. In Manitoba the yield is not likely to average unusually large while Ontario reports generally indicate a good growing crop in general, corn and fall wheat a failure, roots fair but fruits a failure. Reports from private sources are even more discouraging. Some have been grown in place seed which had been sown rotting instead of sprouting owing to the excessively wet season; in others some crops were so poor that they were plowed under. In others land that was prepared was never sown at all. We only want settlers and means to work our lands to make this one of the best growing sections in the Dominion. The farms which have import crops in many localities have passed us by. The small amount of low lying land, the broken nature of our prairie and our sheltered location all tend to keep us safe from either cold winds or fogs.

OUR SCHOOLS.

The opening of the new school on Monday last reminds us that we long for a larger building for our High School. Prince Albert was the first place in the North West Territories for which a school was erected and owing to this and to the otherwise excellent condition of our school it has been able to maintain its high position. Parents and others in the district owe much to the liberality of the Rev. Mr. Macdonald and the Canadian Presbyterian Church for their assistance in establishing and maintaining it, but owing to the increase in the population this assistance has been withdrawn and we have been left to shoulder the entire expense ourselves. The next question of paying the salaries of teachers and other contingent expenses has been eagerly met by the public, but in view of our school census the accommodation is only of a temporary character and unless additional seats have to be provided, in order the Mission one is now unfit for use. The plan of expanding a new school building is now being considered and it will become a more serious burden than the erection of a new school building. Possibly by the end of the year there will be a surplus for the past year amounted to over fifty dollars and an expenditure of not less than $500 will be required in order to fit it up for use during the incoming winter. The time will soon come when it will be necessary to provide for matriculation in Manitoba or Saskatchewan Universities. The question of the location of the school is one of the greatest interests of the different parts of the town will soon be such as to make the school a vital importance. Will not our men and women be the makers of a more commendable school system.

Instructions for Willie Jones.

"Did you ever strike Bridgerton?" asked Willie Jones, who was sitting in his history lesson, who was not up to date in his history lesson.

"Aye," said Mr. Jones, who was sitting on a chair behind the teacher.

"I was speaking philosophically," said Mr. Jones.

There was silence for a few moments. Then Willie came to another speech in his history.

"Ma, who was Julius Caesar?"

"An old soldier man who lived with Julius Caesar," said Mrs. Jones.

"What did he say about him there?"

"It says his wife's name was Cleopatra."

"The very same. Old Cleo used to wash for us. It's strange how they come to be in such beds."

"Honey, honey (she murmured), Jones, so young, while Willie looked at his ma with wonder and admiration that one day he could carry all she knew. Presently he found his mother had to ask,

"Who, who, who was Julius Caesar?"

Whip, which was one of the pupils of his history and Mrs. Jones, trying to thread the point of her needle.

"But what made him famous?" persisted Willie.

"Everything," answered Mrs. Jones, emphatically.

"Everything," echoed Willie. "That's right, Miss Jane. Which is how people would take its oats. He dressed in a sleek and pillar-case uniform, and when his ears were surrounded him he shouted, 'Give me liberty or give me death,' and ran away."

"Bully for Julius!" answered Mrs. Jones, enthusiastically.

"That's right, Miss Jane. Which is how people would take its oats. He dressed in a sleek and pillar-case uniform, and when his ears were surrounded him he shouted, 'Give me liberty or give me death,' and ran away."

"CARROT RIVER.

The present population of Carrot River is about 125. It would have been far easier to settle a town of that size, had it not been for the surveys which have been ordered by the government in the survey of the surrounding townships. They have been ordered because the surveys which have been ordered do not cover the whole area. As there are no even roads, no bridges, no fences, no houses, and only isolated farms, a large number who intended to have settled permanently in the town are now looking for some other spot in which to settle. However, the main purpose of our Ottawa rulers is to make sure that the town is not deserted by any monopolists who obtained their votes. Very patriotic, is it not? The town will be able to send representatives into the legislature in the near future.

THOMAS O. DAVIS.

CHIT-CHAT LOCALS.

Gathered by our Reporters.

The water in the river is rising. The farmers are getting busy. The weather is very fine. Wheat will be ready to cut out in a few days.

The farmers in this vicinity have commenced cutting their barley. The telegraph operators still sit on strike, but there is no excitement.

We have received a communication from Justice J. Campbell which will appear shortly.

Know A Barker, contractor for the erection of the future hall are pushing the work along.

No news of the Lily, further than she had left for Edmonton. She may be looked for any day.

Mr. Fred Baker, of the firm of Walters & Co., has left for the east yesterday. He will visit his family.

Mr. J. J. Fanning, representing James O'Hara's wholesale clothing, of Winnipeg and Montreal, is here.

The body of Capt. Walsh has been found, buried and unmarked. It has been forwarded back to Winnipeg.

A regular meeting of Kinloch Lodge, A.F. & A.M., was held last night in the Masonic Hall Friday, 15th inst.

The Indian department of this district have about 1,000 acres under crop this year. The crops are looking good.

Tenders are being asked for the erection of a new school building at the Blackfoot Reserve.

A.M. Mitchell, Esq., has been appointed to the position.

There was an exchange of polite words between the Presbyterian and Methodist ministers last Sabbath evening. This exchange of friendly feeling gave satisfaction to all present.

The trustees of the public school have been unable to pay Mr. John Stewart, balance of money from school match, and $47.25, per Mr. H. R. Ross, of Calgary.

The town of Cassiar, near Naples, has been nearly destroyed by an earthquake. The buildings of Cassiar, Nelson and Lillooet are greatly damaged. The loss of life is estimated at about 600.

The business hitherto carried on and known as the firm of Stobart, Eden & Co., will be continued by Messrs. Stobart & Co., with the same name and style of O. E. Hughes & Co. All debts due the old firm must be paid to the new firm.

On Monday afternoon, Mr. W. A. McLean while enjoying a concert on his favorite instrument, was hit and killed by his horse stumbling and falling. Happily the only result was a slightly broken shin bone.

Mr. Wm. Dobbin is erecting a brick cottage in rear of the Presbyterian Church. The contractor is doing the brick work. Mr. Geo. Brown, made quick time with his part of the building, by getting it completed last week.

No summons against anyone will be issued from the office of the clerk of the court, until after (or) during the proper fees in advance. Service fees and mileage must be arranged for with the bailiff, as he shall be responsible for them.

James Clark, the laborer who was killed by a mule, was killed July 27th, south of Prince Albert. He was employed by Mr. Peter Hansen, who lives near the College, Prince Albert.

The Hon. L. Clarke received a message from Battleford saying that the Mambert had arrived at Battleford on the 27th inst., and left again at 3 p.m. for Prince Albert. Mr. Mambert had been away for some time.

Also that the Northcote had arrived here on the 27th inst., and that Mr. Mambert had returned for eighty tons loaded as per message from Battleford.

The water was high and rising.

Mr. Mambert was returning home back while on his way to Carrot River last Wednesday morning, when he met with an accident. While engaged in feeding cattle, the wheel of the buckboard struck a stone, Mr. Mambert fell from the seat over the dashboard. In half fall his legs were caught in the buckboard, and the wheel of the buckboard, locked fast as in a vice, crushed his legs. He died instantly near the house boat. The tightened bowstring prevented the buckboard from going the danger of the position. Further explanation would be useless, as it proved any more dangerous result than a severe beating.

House is in moderate demand at this time.

It will be seen by advertisement, the Canada Life Assurance Company have purchased an old residence, now with Mr. H. B. Porter, left yesterday to take up residence in the new house on Mr. J. Agnew's building. We trust he will find it to his satisfaction.

W. J. Nevin of Winnipeg arrived here last week. He brought with him two buggies, two wagons, six horses and quantity of miscellaneous goods, all of which will be sold at public auction without reserve, at the Grand Union Hotel, Prince Albert, Friday the 26th inst., at noon.
